prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCO+, HCN, H13CO+, H13CN 1-0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the HCO+, HCN, H13CO+, and H13CN 1-0 transitions in mosaic mode towards the Oph A ridge.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The HCO+, HCN, H13CO+ and DCO+ lines detected with the JCMT towards some of the cores of the Oph A ridge show an average line width of about 0.8 km/s. A spectral resolution of ~0.1-0.2 km/s is consequently requested to resolve the line profile.

The DCN/HCN ratio is expected to be enhanced at temperatures of about < 70 K, while the DCO+/HCO+ fractionation is particularly efficient at very low temperatures (< 30 K). In order to observe the expected variations of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN spatial extents (especially towards the embedded sources), we need a spatial resolution sufficiently high to separate the warmer regions from the colder regions. For common low-mass protostars (a few solar luminosities), the temperature drops to 30 K at a radius of ~ 300 AU (i.e. a diameter of 5'' at 120 pc). A resolution of 2'' would be consequently appropriate to see the spatial variation of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN ratios.
The emission of DCO+ and HCO+ can also be extended (> 60 arcsec), as shown in Fig. 2. To recover the flux that could be missing with the 12m array, we need to use the ACA and the TP array as well.
The coverage of the map area was defined so that the regions with the brightest continuum emission, the regions with the brightest DCO+ 5-4 emission and the main proto- and pre-stellar sources of the region are observed (see Figure 2).

Observations of the H13CN 1-0 transitions were carried out with the SEST telescope (beam size of ~ 57'') towards VLA1623 (core P2 in Fig. 2) by Jorgensen et al. (2004). The integrated area of this line (in Tmb) is ~ 1 K km/s. If the other cores show a line flux 5 times lower (0.2 K km/s), it would mean that the flux in a synthesized beam of 2 arcsec is equal to at most 3.8 Jy km/s (unresolved source) and at least 5 mJy km/s (flux evenly distributed in the single dish beam). As the H13CN emission is probably relatively compact (detection of the 3-2 transition for only one source of the ridge), the line should be detected. For example, if we assume that the emission extent is about 5 arcsec, it would mean that the line has a flux of 600 mJy km/s (line peak of 760 mJy for a line width of 0.8 km/s). With a rms of 20 mJy in 0.8 km/s (average line width), the signal-to-noise ratio should consequently be ~38.
The H13CO+ 1-0 line is detected towards VLA1623 with a line flux 3 times higher than the H13CN 1-0 transition. This line should consequently be also detected.
Based on interferometric observations of the source VLA1623 (Looney et al. 2000) at 3 mm, the continuum peak flux should be ~20 mJy/beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CO+, H13CN 3-2 South
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the H13CO+ and H13CN 3-2 transitions in mosaic mode towards the South part of the Oph A ridge (~ 150 pointings). Bonus observations of the HC17O+ and HC15N transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The HCO+, HCN, H13CO+ and DCO+ lines detected with the JCMT towards some of the cores of the Oph A ridge show an average line width of about 0.8 km/s. A spectral resolution of ~0.1-0.2 km/s is consequently requested to resolve the line profile.

The DCN/HCN ratio is expected to be enhanced at temperatures of about < 70 K, while the DCO+/HCO+ fractionation is particularly efficient at very low temperatures (< 30 K). In order to observe the expected variations of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN spatial extents (especially towards the embedded sources), we need a spatial resolution sufficiently high to separate the warmer regions from the colder regions. For common low-mass protostars (a few solar luminosities), the temperature drops to 30 K at a radius of ~ 300 AU (i.e. a diameter of 5'' at 120 pc). A resolution of 2'' would be consequently appropriate to see the spatial variation of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN ratios.
The emission of DCO+ and HCO+ can also be extended (> 60 arcsec), as shown in Fig. 2. To recover the flux that could be missing with the 12m array, we need to use the ACA and the TP array as well.
The coverage of the map area was defined so that the regions with the brightest continuum emission, the regions with the brightest DCO+ 5-4 emission and the main proto- and pre-stellar sources of the region are observed (see Figure 2).

Observations were carried out with the JCMT (beam size of ~ 19'') towards 8 cores of the Oph A ridge (see Fig. 2).
The H13CN 3-2 line was detected towards the core N5 with an integrated flux of 2 K km/s (in Tmb). An upper limit of 0.5 K km/s is obtained for the other cores. Assuming that the intensity of this line is ~0.1 K km/s towards these other cores, it would mean that the flux in a synthesized beam of 2 arcsec is at most 1.9 Jy km/s (unresolved source) and at least 20 mJy km/s (flux evenly distributed in the single dish beam). As the H13CN emission is probably relatively compact (detection for only one source of the ridge), the line should be detected. For example, if we assume that the emission extent is about 5 arcsec, it would mean that the line has a flux of 300 mJy km/s (line peak of 375 mJy for a line width of 0.8 km/s). With a rms of 20 mJy in 0.8 km/s (average line width), the signal-to-noise ratio should consequently be ~19.
The H13CO+ 3-2 line is detected towards the 8 cores targeted with the JCMT. The line fluxes vary from 1 K km/s to 5 K km/s. Even in the case where the flux is evenly distributed in the single dish beam, the line could be easily detected. Indeed, in this case, 1 K km/s would be equivalent to 200 mJy km/s. The signal-to noise ratio of the H13CO+ 3-2 line will be necessarily higher than 12.
Based on interferometric observations of the source VLA 1623 (Maury et al. 2012, Murillo et al. 2013) at 1.3 mm, the continuum peak flux should be ~200 mJy/beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CO+, H13CN 3-2 North
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the H13CO+ and H13CN 3-2 transitions in mosaic mode towards the North part of the Oph A ridge (~ 150 pointings). Bonus observations of the HC17O+ and HC15N transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The HCO+, HCN, H13CO+ and DCO+ lines detected with the JCMT towards some of the cores of the Oph A ridge show an average line width of about 0.8 km/s. A spectral resolution of ~0.1-0.2 km/s is consequently requested to resolve the line profile.

The DCN/HCN ratio is expected to be enhanced at temperatures of about < 70 K, while the DCO+/HCO+ fractionation is particularly efficient at very low temperatures (< 30 K). In order to observe the expected variations of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN spatial extents (especially towards the embedded sources), we need a spatial resolution sufficiently high to separate the warmer regions from the colder regions. For common low-mass protostars (a few solar luminosities), the temperature drops to 30 K at a radius of ~ 300 AU (i.e. a diameter of 5'' at 120 pc). A resolution of 2'' would be consequently appropriate to see the spatial variation of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN ratios.
The emission of DCO+ and HCO+ can also be extended (> 60 arcsec), as shown in Fig. 2. To recover the flux that could be missing with the 12m array, we need to use the ACA and the TP array as well.
The coverage of the map area was defined so that the regions with the brightest continuum emission, the regions with the brightest DCO+ 5-4 emission and the main proto- and pre-stellar sources of the region are observed (see Figure 2).

Observations were carried out with the JCMT (beam size of ~ 19'') towards 8 cores of the Oph A ridge (see Fig. 2).
The H13CN 3-2 line was detected towards the core N5 with an integrated flux of 2 K km/s (in Tmb). An upper limit of 0.5 K km/s is obtained for the other cores. Assuming that the intensity of this line is ~0.1 K km/s towards these other cores, it would mean that the flux in a synthesized beam of 2 arcsec is at most 1.9 Jy km/s (unresolved source) and at least 20 mJy km/s (flux evenly distributed in the single dish beam). As the H13CN emission is probably relatively compact (detection for only one source of the ridge), the line should be detected. For example, if we assume that the emission extent is about 5 arcsec, it would mean that the line has a flux of 300 mJy km/s (line peak of 375 mJy for a line width of 0.8 km/s). With a rms of 20 mJy in 0.8 km/s (average line width), the signal-to-noise ratio should consequently be ~19.
The H13CO+ 3-2 line is detected towards the 8 cores targeted with the JCMT. The line fluxes vary from 1 K km/s to 5 K km/s. Even in the case where the flux is evenly distributed in the single dish beam, the line could be easily detected. Indeed, in this case, 1 K km/s would be equivalent to 200 mJy km/s. The signal-to noise ratio of the H13CO+ 3-2 line will be necessarily higher than 12.
Based on interferometric observations of the source VLA 1623 (Maury et al. 2012, Murillo et al. 2013) at 1.3 mm, the continuum peak flux should be ~200 mJy/beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: DCO+, DCN 3-2 South
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the DCO+ and DCN 3-2 transitions in mosaic mode towards the South part of the Oph A ridge. Bonus observation of a NH2D transition and a N2D+ transition.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The HCO+, HCN, H13CO+ and DCO+ lines detected with the JCMT towards some of the cores of the Oph A ridge show an average line width of about 0.8 km/s. A spectral resolution of ~0.1-0.2 km/s is consequently requested to resolve the line profile.

The DCN/HCN ratio is expected to be enhanced at temperatures of about < 70 K, while the DCO+/HCO+ fractionation is particularly efficient at very low temperatures (< 30 K). In order to observe the expected variations of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN spatial extents (especially towards the embedded sources), we need a spatial resolution sufficiently high to separate the warmer regions from the colder regions. For common low-mass protostars (a few solar luminosities), the temperature drops to 30 K at a radius of ~ 300 AU (i.e. a diameter of 5'' at 120 pc). A resolution of 2'' would be consequently appropriate to see the spatial variation of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN ratios.
The emission of DCO+ and HCO+ can also be extended (> 60 arcsec), as shown in Fig. 2. To recover the flux that could be missing with the 12m array, we need to use the ACA and the TP array as well.
The coverage of the map area was defined so that the regions with the brightest continuum emission, the regions with the brightest DCO+ 5-4 emission and the main proto- and pre-stellar sources of the region are observed (see Figure 2).

Observations were carried out with the JCMT (beam size of ~ 23'')towards 8 cores of the Oph A ridge (see Fig. 2).
The DCN 3-2 line was detected towards 3 of the cores with an integrated flux between 0.5 and 0.8 K km/s (in Tmb). An upper limit of 0.3 K km/s is obtained for the other cores. Assuming that the intensity of this line is ~0.1 K km/s towards these other cores, it would mean that the flux in a synthesized beam of 2 arcsec is at most 1.9 Jy km/s (unresolved source) and at least 14 mJy km/s (flux evenly distributed in the single dish beam). As the DCN emission is expected to be compact (enhancement in regions at high temperature, T < 70 K), the line should be detected. For example, if we assume that the emission extent is about 5 arcsec, it would mean that the line has a flux of 300 mJy km/s (line peak of 375 mJy for a line width of 0.8 km/s). With a rms of 20 mJy in 0.8 km/s (average line width), the signal-to-noise ratio should consequently be ~19.
The DCO+ 3-2 line is detected towards 7 of the cores targeted with the JCMT. The line fluxes vary from 0.6 K km/s to 6 K km/s. Even in the case where the flux is evenly distributed in the single dish beam, the line can be detected. Indeed, in this case, 0.6 K km/s would be equivalent to 84 mJy km/s. The signal-to noise ratio of the DCO+ 3-2 line will be necessarily higher than 5.
Based on interferometric observations of the source VLA 1623 (Maury et al. 2012, Murillo et al. 2013) at 1.3 mm, the continuum peak flux should be ~200 mJy/beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: DCO+, DCN 3-2 North
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the DCO+ and DCN 3-2 transitions in mosaic mode towards the North part of the Oph A ridge. Bonus observation of a NH2D transition and a N2D+ transition.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The HCO+, HCN, H13CO+ and DCO+ lines detected with the JCMT towards some of the cores of the Oph A ridge show an average line width of about 0.8 km/s. A spectral resolution of ~0.1-0.2 km/s is consequently requested to resolve the line profile.

The DCN/HCN ratio is expected to be enhanced at temperatures of about < 70 K, while the DCO+/HCO+ fractionation is particularly efficient at very low temperatures (< 30 K). In order to observe the expected variations of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN spatial extents (especially towards the embedded sources), we need a spatial resolution sufficiently high to separate the warmer regions from the colder regions. For common low-mass protostars (a few solar luminosities), the temperature drops to 30 K at a radius of ~ 300 AU (i.e. a diameter of 5'' at 120 pc). A resolution of 2'' would be consequently appropriate to see the spatial variation of the DCO+/HCO+ and DCN/HCN ratios.
The emission of DCO+ and HCO+ can also be extended (> 60 arcsec), as shown in Fig. 2. To recover the flux that could be missing with the 12m array, we need to use the ACA and the TP array as well.
The coverage of the map area was defined so that the regions with the brightest continuum emission, the regions with the brightest DCO+ 5-4 emission and the main proto- and pre-stellar sources of the region are observed (see Figure 2).

Observations were carried out with the JCMT (beam size of ~ 23'') towards 8 cores of the Oph A ridge (see Fig. 2).
The DCN 3-2 line was detected towards 3 of the cores with an integrated flux between 0.5 and 0.8 K km/s (in Tmb). An upper limit of 0.3 K km/s is obtained for the other cores. Assuming that the intensity of this line is ~0.1 K km/s towards these other cores, it would mean that the flux in a synthesized beam of 2 arcsec is at most 1.9 Jy km/s (unresolved source) and at least 14 mJy km/s (flux evenly distributed in the single dish beam). As the DCN emission is expected to be compact (enhancement in regions at high temperature, T < 70 K), the line should be detected. For example, if we assume that the emission extent is about 5 arcsec, it would mean that the line has a flux of 300 mJy km/s (line peak of 375 mJy for a line width of 0.8 km/s). With a rms of 20 mJy in 0.8 km/s (average line width), the signal-to-noise ratio should consequently be ~19.
The DCO+ 3-2 line is detected towards 7 of the cores targeted with the JCMT. The line fluxes vary from 0.6 K km/s to 6 K km/s. Even in the case where the flux is evenly distributed in the single dish beam, the line can be detected. Indeed, in this case, 0.6 K km/s would be equivalent to 84 mJy km/s. The signal-to noise ratio of the DCO+ 3-2 line will be necessarily higher than 5.
Based on interferometric observations of the source VLA 1623 (Maury et al. 2012, Murillo et al. 2013) at 1.3 mm, the continuum peak flux should be ~200 mJy/beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Deuterium enhancements in HCN and HCO+ were suggested to result from different chemical pathways, whose efficiency depends on temperature (<70K for HCN vs <30K for HCO+). They could consequently be used as a tracer of the physical conditions and/or evolution. Several previous studies have compared the deuterium fractionation of molecules in samples of pre- and proto-stellar cores, but only across many different regions, where the "initial conditions", such as abundances and timescales, could be different. We propose here to observe HCO+, HCN, H13CO+, H13CN, DCO+, and DCN in mosaic mode towards the Oph-A star-forming ridge to derive, for the first time, the DCN/HCN and DCO+/HCO+ ratios in a spatially confined region with small variations in "initial conditions". With these observations, we will compare the variation of the DCN/HCN and DCO+/HCO+ ratios at a spatial resolution of 2'' and determine if they can be used as a robust tracer of physical conditions. In particular, a different origin in the deuteration of these two molecules would be confirmed if the areas with the highest DCN/HCN ratios are spatially different from those with the highest DCO+/HCO+ ratios.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: A VLA proposal (PI: M. van der Wiel) was submitted for semester 2015B to map the NH3 (1,1), (2,2) and (3,3) lines towards Oph A .
